childItems.text:
Select the next entry with 'arrow key down'

With 'arrow key left' you collapse an entry
If that is not possible, the parent entry is selected instead
Expand all children with 'Shift+arrow key right'

Press 'Tab' (the key left of 'Q') to edit the text of an entry
'Enter' finishes editing
When you press 'Shift+Enter' during editing, you insert a line break
Each change is immediately safed. When you close the application you will continue where you left off.
Move the selected entry or the selected entries with 'W' und 'S' vertically
Indent the selected entries with 'D'. It will be the child of the entry above it.
This way entries can be moved in all four directions

Focus the search field with 'Ctrl+F'.
Type in it. The tree will be filtered.
Focus the tree again with 'arrow key down'.
Empty the search field with 'Esc'.
Searching for 'blue' finds 'a blue flower' but not 'bluetooth'. Searching for '*blue*' finds 'bluetooth'.

Select this entry and press 'L' to open the contained URL in your web browser
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dsfROmgVN5U
Select this entry and press 'L' to google its text
Color an entry with e.g. with 'R'
All available colors are listed in the menu 'Edit row -> Color selected rows'
Now extend this tree with your own notes and todos!
Shift+Click on an entry to create a coherent selection
When moving with e.g. 'W' or coloring with e.g. 'G' the action is always done for the whole selection
The text of selected entries is copied to the clipboard with 'Ctrl+C'
Wenn du den Baum hier drunter vollständig ausklappst, alle Einträge selektierst, dann mit 'Strg+C' kopierst und in einem Texteditor einfügst...
...dann wird er so eingefügt, dass die Baumstruktur erhalten bleibt:
Wenn du eine solche baumartige Stichpunkt-Liste in einem Texteditor kopierst und hier einfügst, werden daraus wieder viele baumartige Einträge
Show and hide the sidebars with the blue button in the top right
Click on 'Filters' in the right sidebar to show the available filters
Choose e.g. in the 'Color' drop down menu the item 'green'. This inserts some text into the search field which filter the items of the tree.
If you are faster with the keyboard you can as well just type 'color=green' oor 'c=g' in the search bar

Words which start with a colon are displayed in green and get listed in the right sidebar below 'Tags', e.g. :tag
Click on a tag inside that list to filter the tree for that tag
You can rename tags with a right-click on them
You can structure tags hierarchically by concatenating them, e.g. :People:Mum and :People:Jonas
Press 'space' to change the type of an entry from note to task. A checkbox appears in front of the entry.
Press 'space' again to mark the task as done
Press 'space' a third time to change the type to note again
Below the menubar there is a path bar. It shows which entry is currently opened, similar to the path bar of Windows Explorer and Finder of Mac OS X.
Open the parent entry of the current opened entry with 'Ctrl + arrow key up'
Click on '/' in the path bar to open the root of the whole tree again
You can press "Esc" to open the root as well

Select this entry. 
Press "Ctrl + arrow key down" to open the selected entry as the root of the tree view. Then only its children are visible yet.

The whole tree is visible in the left sidebar 'quick access'.
Click on an entry there to open it in the main view
The tag sidebar on the right only shows tags of entries which are children of the current opened entry
If you are not using time-management / Getting Things Done you can hide the needless columns with "Shift+C". Then the tree is smaller and looks better for long entries.
Click on the yellow star to save a search
Click on a saved bookmark in the sidebar, to fill its text into the search field again
Select a date with the arrow keys
Or type e.g. '125' for the date '12.05.'
Set a start date per keystroke e.g. '1w' for 'in one week'
Press 'tab' two times to edit the start date of an entry
The filter "Date until: 1d" shows all entries, whose start date is at most tomorrow. I bookmarked this filter and open it every day.
Apart from my project list I have an entry called 'Tasks' or 'Next actions'. It's children are a long list of tasks,  some of them have a start date or a tag.

To see available tasks only I created a bookmark, which has the two filters 'Hide rows with a future start date' and 'Hide rows with a tag'. Furthermore I don't want to search the whole tree but the entry 'Tasks' only. Therefore I checked 'Save current root item' when I created the bookmark.
Edit a task so it contains the text repeat=1w and has a start date
If you complete it, its start date is increased by one week
You can also use repeat=1d 1w 1m 1y for day, week month or year
Set the estimated length of an entry with the keys '6' and then '0' to 60 minutes. More key combinations are found in the menu 'Edit entry'.
Sort the rows by clicking on the headers 'Estimate' or 'Start date'
Press 'P' to toggle the entry type between note, sequential project, parallel project and paused project
Not available tasks in a sequential project are shown in grey and are not found when filtering for tasks, until the tasks above them are not yet done
Tasks from paused projects are not found either
Tasks from parallel projects are found normally, since they can be done in any order
Functions for time-management, e.g. Getting Things Done
You can move the selected entry below any other entry of the tree with 'F'
You can print the currently visible part of the tree with 'Ctrg+P'
If you type # and then any letter during editing an entry, all other entries which start with that letter are listed. Enter insert a suggestion and an internal link is created, e.g. #Internal links#
Open an internal link by pressing 'L'
Copy a file in your file manager and paste it in TreeNote
The key 'L' opens not only web URLs, but also pasted file URLs
Open the folder of a file with '.'
TreeNote is able to create a backup of the tree e.g. every 30 minutes. If you delete an entry an notice it a first days later, you can open a backup with 'File -> Import'

To enable automatic backups open 'File -> Preferences' and choose a backup folder and a backup interval. I recommend choosing a backup folder on a HDD, not on a SSD since SSD drives perish with many write operations.
You can change the theme / the background color of TreeNote from dark to bright under 'File -> Preferences'
Explore the menu bar for more functions. For example, you can change the font size under 'View'.
When I work a lot mentally, I feel exhausted...
...to refresh, I do a :relaxing task like emptying the waste
Use tags for locations and people.
You may use colors to mark what you want to do today
When you complete a project, turn it into a note and move it to completed projects
Define a project by adding two notes below it:
Time-management / Getting Things Done with TreeNote
get the packet from the mail office :city :relaxing
look for old stuff to sell on ebayclassifieds.com
make a backup of my computer
check if 'Shantaram' is available at the library now
eat slowly and enjoy the meal
criticise other people from a first person view
the human brain does not understands the word 'not'
This short manual teaches you interactively how to use TreeNote. Expand it with 'arrow key right'!
